utterances: (Soundbite of movie, Office Space)
(As Bill Lumbergh) Hello, Peter.
(As Peter Gibbons) What's happening?
(As Bill Lumbergh) Ahhh, we have sort of a problem here.
Yeah, you apparently didn't put one of the new cover sheets on your TPS reports.
(As Peter Gibbons) Oh, yeah.
I'm sorry about that.
I forgot.
(As Bill Lumbergh) Mmm, yeah.
You see, we're putting the cover sheets on all TPS reports now before they go out.
Did you see the memo about this?
(Soundbite of laughter)
Did you see the memo about this?
It's so cloying.
Let's get a caller in on the line.
This is Marilyn.
Marilyn's calling us from Gold Canyon, Arizona.
Hi, there.
Hi, there.
What a movie, what a boss.
I mean, oh, I think that that guy is just the worst ever.
(Soundbite of laughter)
You sound like somebody who has experience with a boss a little like that.
Well, sort of, yes.
But, yeah.

But for the most part - there is another scene in this film where he just asked him to come in for the weekend -work Saturday, and he said I'm going to need you to work on Sunday and ugh, it's just irritating and awful, so…
It sounds like you can relate to it.
I've had bad bosses, but I think this guy takes the cake, though.
Well, these are all - for the most part, Murray, these are comedies.
They are mostly comedies.
And I think the reason for that is, Neal, that - you know, movies are still, in my view, the greatest cultural force to bring people together.
I mean, you say The Devil Wears Prada, and a whole pile of people of all ages and races and backgrounds know what you're talking about - at least in America - in this summer.
And, so in addition, we, to people we love to love being kind of universal types and we can all relate to…
Sure.
People like Dorothy in The Wizard of Oz, there are people we love to hate, and…
That was Erich Von Stroheim.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Well, I'm telling you, I might go for Frank there in Office Space.
I mean, anybody - whether you had a red stapler or not - who worked in an office in the 1990s can relate to that guy.
There you go.
Marilyn, thanks very much for the call.
My pleasure.
We solicited e-mails from the working masses who listen to National Public Radio's TALK OF THE NATION Summer Movie Festival, asking them to give us their pick for the most devilish boss.
We received this one from Ron Aaron.
Who better or worse than Commander Queeg to be crowned the best of the worst bosses from hell?
He hounded his staff, would not listen to reason, went off on ludicrous tangents, and when confronted with the facts, chose to ignore them.
Makes one wonder whether Herman Wouk knew a Queeg from firsthand, and who can forget Humphrey Bogart's portrayal in the film?
Right.
Close your eyes.
Can't you see and hear Bogart working those ball bearings in his hands?
That's true.
It makes my skin crawl, and joining us now is Ron Aaron.
He's the vice president for institutional advancement at the Winston School in San Antonio, Texas.
Nice to have you on TALK OF THE NATION.
Well, it's great to be aboard.
Thank you.
Captain Queeg welcomes you aboard.
What a great pick.
(Soundbite of laughter)
Chip, thanks very much for the nomination.
We appreciate it.
Yes, no it's true.
You know, I must tell you, Ron, that I - there are sort of two sub-sets of this genre, and I didn't know whether to treat them or not.
One's military bosses, right?

Because it's important to remember Captain Queeg is, himself, the inheritor of the great tradition of Captain Bligh, who was played by both Charles Laughton and Trevor Howard in the movies, alternately terrorizing Clark Gable and Marlon Brando.
And my favorite military boss of all is Sterling Hayden in Dr. Strangelove.
I thought you were going to go, in fact, to Jimmy Cagney as the captain in Mr. Roberts.
Oh, that's a very good one.
I mean, Cagney is horrible, and your flesh crawls when you see them come on the screen.
But Captain Queeg, there is a guy who has absolutely terrorized his entire crew.
Well he has.
And I worked for a guy, years ago, like that in Washington, D.C., so I felt it firsthand.
I am sorry.
Yes, believe me, you would be.
Well, was he nuts like Captain Queeg?
Captain Queeg is crazy.
It's the strawberries, it was the strawberries.
I'll give you a quick example, and I know you're short on time, but he hated my briefcase.
